question:
How many components do bacterial flagella have?

SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• Bacterial flagella have 3 main components:
    1. Basal body – Anchors the flagellum to the cell wall and plasma membrane, and acts as a motor.
    2. Hook – A curved structure that connects the basal body to the filament and transmits torque.
    3. Filament – The long, whip-like part made of flagellin that propels the bacterium.

Additional Information:

  • These three components work together to enable motility in bacteria.
  • The basal body differs structurally in Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria.

question:
What is the diameter size range of the virus?

SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The typical diameter range of viruses is about 20 to 200 nanometers (nm).
  • Most viruses are ultramicroscopic and can only be seen under electron microscopes.
  • For example:
    • Poliovirus: ~30 nm
    • Influenza virus: ~80–120 nm
    • Poxvirus (one of the largest): ~200–300 nm in diameter

Additional Information:

  • 1 nanometer (nm) = 10⁻⁹ meters
  • The small size of viruses allows them to infect living cells by easily entering them.

question:
What is the full form of PPLO with respect to bacteria?

SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)
option_1: Pleuro Platelet Like Organisms
option_2: Platelet Prone Like Organisms
option_3: Pleuro Pneumonia Like Organisms
option_4: Pneumonia Platelet Like Organisms
solution:
• The full form of PPLO is Pleuro Pneumonia Like Organisms.
  • These are bacteria that belong to the Mycoplasma group.
  • PPLOs are the smallest known free-living microorganisms.
  • They lack a cell wall, making them resistant to antibiotics like penicillin.
  • PPLOs are pathogenic and can cause diseases like pleuropneumonia in cattle and respiratory infections in humans.

Additional Information:

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a well-known PPLO that causes atypical pneumonia in humans.
  • They can pass through bacterial filters due to their small size (approx. 0.1 µm).

question:
Which of the following can degrade detritus into simpler inorganic substances?

SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Fungal enzymes are responsible for breaking down detritus (dead organic matter) into simpler inorganic substances like carbon dioxide, water, and minerals.
  • This process is called decomposition, and it plays a vital role in the nutrient cycling of ecosystems.
  • Fungi, especially saprophytic fungi, secrete enzymes that digest complex organic matter externally and absorb the nutrients.

Additional Information:

  • Lichens: Symbiotic association of fungi and algae; not primarily involved in detritus degradation.
  • Algae: Autotrophs that produce oxygen through photosynthesis; they don't decompose detritus.
  • Phytoplankton: Microscopic photosynthetic organisms found in aquatic environments; they are producers, not decomposers.

question:
Which of the following is a kind of Xanthan?

SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• Xanthan gum is a type of microbial gum, produced by the bacterium Xanthomonas campestris.
  • It is formed through fermentation of sugars and used widely as a thickening and stabilizing agent in food and industrial products.
  • It is not derived from plants, unlike seed, seaweed, or exudate gums.

Additional Information:

  • Seed gum: Derived from seeds (e.g., guar gum, locust bean gum).
  • Seaweed gum: Extracted from marine algae (e.g., agar, carrageenan).
  • Exudate gum: Obtained from plant exudates (e.g., gum arabic from Acacia trees).
  • Microbial gum: Produced by microbial fermentation (e.g., xanthan gum, gellan gum).

question:
Creaming fat and sugar, whipping egg whites, or whipping heavy cream are examples of what type of leavening?

SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Creaming fat and sugar, whipping egg whites, and whipping heavy cream are all examples of mechanical leavening.
  • In mechanical leavening, air is physically incorporated into the batter or dough through actions like beating, whisking, or creaming.
  • This trapped air expands during baking, making the final product light and fluffy.

Additional Information:

  • Organic leavening: Refers to biological processes, usually involving yeast.
  • Physical leavening: Broad term that may refer to changes due to heat or steam (but not specific like mechanical).
  • Chemical leavening: Involves baking soda or baking powder, which release gases like CO₂ when reacting with moisture or acids.

question:
Which of the following pairs of microorganism-type is correct?

I. Paramecium – Fungi

II. Penicillium – Protozoa

SSC CPO 10/11/2022 (Evening)
option_2: Both I and II
option_3: Neither I nor II
solution:
• Paramecium is a protozoan, not a fungus. It is a unicellular eukaryotic organism that moves using cilia and lives in freshwater environments.
  • Penicillium is a fungus, not a protozoan. It is a genus of fungi used in the production of antibiotics like penicillin and in food processing (e.g., cheese).

Thus, both statements are incorrect.

Additional Information:

  • Protozoa: Microscopic, single-celled organisms like Paramecium, Amoeba, etc.
  • Fungi: Multicellular or unicellular organisms like Penicillium, Yeast, Mushrooms, etc.

question:
Which aquatic microoganisms eat phytoplankton and then become food for fish, crustaceans and other large species?

SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• Zooplankton are microscopic aquatic animals that feed on phytoplankton (plant-like microscopic organisms).
  • They form a crucial link in the aquatic food chain, as they are primary consumers and serve as food for fish, crustaceans, and larger aquatic species.
  • Examples of zooplankton include copepods, daphnia, and rotifers.

Additional Information:

  • Virioplankton: Viruses found in aquatic environments; they infect bacteria and plankton.
  • Bacterioplankton: Bacteria in planktonic form; help in decomposition and nutrient cycling.
  • Zooxanthellae: Symbiotic algae found in corals, not plankton that feed on phytoplankton.

question:
What kind of adaptation is seen in bacteria when they form various kinds of thick-walled spores.

SSC CHSL 01/06/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• When bacteria form thick-walled spores, it is a type of suspensive adaptation.
  • This process is known as sporulation, where bacteria form endospores to survive in unfavorable environmental conditions like heat, desiccation, radiation, or chemical exposure.
  • These spores help the bacteria remain dormant but viable, allowing them to "pause" life processes and resume growth once conditions improve.

Additional Information:

  • Suspend: Refers to halting normal functions temporarily – accurate in this context.
  • Migrate: Movement from one place to another – not related to spore formation.
  • Conform: Adapting to environmental changes without resistance – not applicable here.
  • Regulate: Control or maintain – not the specific response shown during spore formation.

question:
Which unicellular organism acquires food by a process in which cells absorb external material by engulfing it with the cell membrane?

SSC CHSL 02/06/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• Amoeba is a unicellular organism that acquires food through phagocytosis, a process in which the cell membrane engulfs external particles like food by forming pseudopodia.
  • This is a classic example of endocytosis, specifically cell eating (phagocytosis).
  • The engulfed material is enclosed in a food vacuole, where it is digested by enzymes.

Additional Information:

  • Yeast: A unicellular fungus that absorbs nutrients through the cell surface but does not use phagocytosis.
  • Volvox: A colonial alga, not known for engulfing food via the cell membrane.
  • Spirogyra: A filamentous green alga that performs photosynthesis and does not engulf food.

question:
Which algae produces agar?

SSC CHSL 06/06/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• Gracilaria is a red algae that is one of the main sources of agar.
  • Agar is a gelatinous substance extracted from the cell walls of red algae, particularly Gracilaria and Gelidium species.
  • It is widely used in microbiology labs as a culture medium and also in food industry as a vegetarian substitute for gelatin.

Additional Information:

  • Chlorella: A green algae, used as a protein-rich food supplement, not for agar.
  • Sargassum: A brown algae, not used to produce agar.
  • Align: Likely a misspelling; possibly intended to be algin, which is derived from brown algae like Laminaria, but not the source of agar.

question:
Which is the toxin-causing bacterium that spoils cream, cheese and milk and makes them taste bitter, sour or bitter?

SSC CHSL 07/06/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Bacillus cereus is a toxin-producing bacterium that contaminates dairy products like cream, cheese, and milk.
  • It can cause spoilage by making the food taste bitter, sour, or unpleasant.
  • B. cereus is also known to produce heat-stable toxins that can lead to food poisoning if ingested in large amounts.

Additional Information:

  • Streptococcus thermophilus: Used in yogurt and cheese production; beneficial, not a spoilage organism.
  • Bifidobacterium: A probiotic bacterium beneficial to gut health, not associated with spoilage.
  • Lactobacillus plantarum: Also a probiotic, used in fermentation processes; does not spoil dairy products.

question:
What is a biotechnological process accomplished by yeast, some type of bacteria, or some other microorganism to convert sugar into ethyl alcohol and carbon dioxide?

SSC CHSL 07/06/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The process of alcoholic fermentation is a biotechnological method where yeast or certain microorganisms convert sugar (glucose) into ethyl alcohol (ethanol) and carbon dioxide.
  • This process is anaerobic (occurs without oxygen) and is used in the production of alcoholic beverages like beer and wine.
  • Chemical equation:

    Glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆) → Ethanol (C₂H₅OH) + CO₂ + Energy

Additional Information:

  • Pasteurisation: Heat treatment to kill microbes in liquids like milk, not related to alcohol production.
  • Lactic acid fermentation: Converts sugar into lactic acid, not alcohol; occurs in muscles and yogurt-making.
  • Glycolysis: A part of cellular respiration, breaking down glucose into pyruvate; it precedes fermentation.

question:
Identify the algae that is NOT a marine algae.

SSC CHSL 07/06/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• Chlorella is a freshwater green algae, not marine.
  • It is a unicellular algae rich in proteins and vitamins, often used as a dietary supplement and in biotechnology for biofuel and wastewater treatment.
  • The other three options are marine algae, commonly found in ocean environments.

Additional Information:

  • Sargassum: A brown marine algae, floating in large masses in oceans.
  • Porphyra: A red marine algae, used in making nori (edible seaweed).
  • Laminaria: A brown marine algae, commonly used in fertilizers and food industry.

question:
Tooth decay is caused by ___________ .

SSC MTS 11/10/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Tooth decay is primarily caused by bacteria, especially Streptococcus mutans.
  • These bacteria feed on sugars in the food we eat and produce acid as a byproduct.
  • The acid erodes the enamel (outer layer of the tooth), leading to cavities and decay.

Additional Information:

  • Viruses: Do not cause tooth decay, though they can affect oral health in other ways.
  • Fungi: Can cause oral infections (like thrush), but not decay.
  • Protozoa: Not linked with tooth decay in humans.

question:
Which of the following popular kitchen ingredients is called the ‘sugar eating fungus’?

SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Yeast is commonly known as the “sugar-eating fungus.”
  • It is a unicellular fungus that feeds on sugar and converts it into carbon dioxide and alcohol through the process of fermentation.
  • Yeast is widely used in baking (to make dough rise) and brewing (to produce alcoholic beverages).

Additional Information:

  • Vinegar: A liquid containing acetic acid, made by fermenting alcohol.
  • Baking powder: A chemical leavening agent; it doesn’t contain live organisms.
  • Ketchup: A condiment made from tomatoes, vinegar, and spices; not a fungus or fermentation agent.

question:
Melatonin encodes proteins in cells to prevent ________ entry.

SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Melatonin is a hormone produced by the pineal gland in the brain, primarily known for regulating the sleep-wake cycle.
  • Recent research has shown that melatonin can also play a role in cellular defense mechanisms.
  • It helps encode certain proteins that can inhibit the entry of viruses into cells, thereby providing antiviral protection.
  • This is particularly relevant in studies involving viral infections like influenza and coronaviruses.

Additional Information:

  • Bacterium, protozoan, and fungus are also pathogens but are not the specific target in this context.
  • Melatonin’s immunomodulatory and antioxidant properties help boost overall immunity.

question:
Cuscuta is an example of:

SSC CHSL 05/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• Cuscuta, commonly known as dodder, is a parasite.
  • It lacks chlorophyll, so it cannot perform photosynthesis and cannot make its own food.
  • Instead, it wraps around host plants and inserts haustoria (sucking roots) into the host’s vascular system to absorb nutrients and water.
  • This weakens the host plant and can severely affect its growth.

Additional Information:

  • Autotroph: Organisms that make their own food via photosynthesis (e.g., green plants).
  • Saprotroph: Organisms that feed on dead or decaying matter (e.g., fungi).
  • Host: The organism that supports a parasite.
